conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a light source, creating a dark area on a surface.
The size and position of the shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface where the shadow is cast.
There are four objects casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D, with the light source positioned above these objects.
As the light source moves backward, the angle at which light hits the objects changes, causing the shadows to shift in position.
If the light source moves backward, the shadows will move forward (away from the light source).
The distance between the light source and the objects increases as the light source moves backward, generally causing the shadows to become larger.
The further the light source is from the objects, the more the light rays spread out, resulting in longer and larger shadows.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move forward on the ground as the light source moves backward.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will become larger as the light source moves backward.
